question: I have been diagnosed with epicondylitis recently, however, I have begun to believe the diagnosis is dubious.  I have a tingling, numb sensation in both of my hands, usually the right and I could simply wake up from a nap feeling like my arm has been held up over my head and then lowered into a normal position or plugged into a mild electrical charge.  I have been waiting for about three weeks for the results of blood tests after a receptionist set up an appointment and mentioned the possibility of diabetes.  However, other than high cholesterol, my tests came normal—no diabetes—and was given a neoprene band with pressure points to wrap around my forarm tendons for a few weeks.  Aside from being an uncomfortable nuisance, it really isn't doing much.  I'm an avid pool player, but I don't put much stress on my arms, I feel no pain in my elbows, or any real pain for that matter and the electrical numbness I feel in my hands also exists occasionally in my feet.  I suspect it's neurological, but it won't be until later this month before I see a neurologist as I need to determine if I need to continue using the anti-convulsion medication I've been on for the last 4 years or at least get refills.  I'd be happy to get some advice, especially with someone with a similar condition.
title: Lateral epicondylitis
